What Our Families SayLearn what our families say about being a part of Spring Lake Park Schools.
Nutrition ServicesIt’s proven when kids eat a well-nourished meal they learn better and play harder. That’s why we concentrate on serving fresh, nutritious and tasty choices.
Athletics and ActivitiesThere are many athletic and activity opportunities for students to get involved and extend their learning beyond the classroom.
Personalized LearningEach student in Spring Lake Park Schools is known by name, strength, interest and need, leading to personalized student work and learning experiences!
Career and College ReadinessOur vision to have every student prepared for college is bold and highly aspirational.

li.a: Social Work and Community Resource Liaison
Social Work and Community Resource Liaison

div.p: April 23, 2020

Governor Walz ordered K-12 schools in Minnesota to remain closed through the end of the 2019-2020 school year. In addition, the Minnesota State High School League has canceled the spring athletic and fine arts season. These steps are being taken to slow the spread of COVID-19 in our community.
While this is not how we wanted to end the school year, we are focused on making the best of this situation and thankful for the support and partnership of our entire learning community.

li.p: We will end the year through Extended Flexible Learning. We continue to refine instructional practices and seek an appropriate balance of activities and connection. We will double down on these efforts to make extended flexible learning for the remainder of the school year the best experience we possibly can.

May 1 and May 4 there will be no student instruction days as teachers plan for the rest of the year. The governor had previously closed schools through April 30 with planning days on May 1 and May 4 in anticipation of schools reopening on May 5. We will use these planning days to prepare for the last six weeks of the year. In addition, next week, we will be asking for feedback on how extended flexible learning is going for families and use the feedback to inform our planning.

Meal service and child care continue. The district is continuing to provide essential meal delivery services to community children and child care services for health care workers and emergency responders during this time.

We are looking at all spring events.
Spring in our schools brings many important events and milestones. Over the next few weeks, we will be making decisions about what to postpone, do differently or cancel.

We have postponed prom and graduation. Our plans will continue to be subject to changing conditions, and we remain hopeful we can preserve these experiences - specifically for the Class of 2020. Prom is reschedule to Friday, June 26 and High School Graduation is rescheduled to Saturday, August 1. More details to come.

ul.li: Please see the appropriate school newsletter for school- specific information on extended flexible learning. Links to school newsletters can be found on the newsletters page. The primary, day-to-day communication between students and families is now at the building and classroom level.

div.p: Please continue to check here for the latest information.

li.a: How is the school district making decisions about how to respond to the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19)?
What is happening with prom and graduation?
Do I need to pay iPad insurance on the iPad my K-3 student is receiving for home use?
What if we do not have wireless access at home?
Does my child still have access to food?
Is child care available for health care workers and other first responders?
What is happening with second trimester report cards?
Is the school year being extended?
What if I still have things at school that I need?
How will you communicate any changes to how schools are operating?

h2.a: How is the school district making decisions about how to respond to the novel Coronavirus (COVID-19)?

div.p: Our decision-making is guided by the Minnesota Department of Health, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Minnesota Department of Education. Based on their guidance and our specific operating issues, we are working to make decisions that safeguard health and wellbeing and support continuity in providing effective, engaging learning.

h2.a: What is happening with prom and graduation?

div.p: We are doing everything we can to preserve milestone events and some capacity - especially for graduating seniors. We have postponed prom and graduation to new dates:
Our plans will continue to be subject to changing conditions, and we remain hopeful we can move forward with these events in some capacity.

h2.a: Do I need to pay iPad insurance on the iPad my K-3 student is receiving for home use?

div.p: No. The insurance is being waived for this current situation.

h2.a: What if we do not have wireless access at home?

div.p: We have identified low or no-cost wireless access options through Comcast and Xfinity. Please find more information about these options on the wireless access page.

h2.a: Does my child still have access to food?

div.p: Yes. Spring Lake Park Schools is providing meals to children in our community during this school closure. We are providing a bagged breakfast and lunch option for children ages 1-18 at no cost.
See more information about pickup locations on the Meal Services page.

h2.a: Is child care available for health care workers and other first responders?

div.p: Yes. Spring Lake Parks Schools is providing free school-age supervision to children whose parents are health care workers and first responders. Care is available 6:30 a.m.- 6 p.m. Check out the Child Care section for additional information.
Minnesota State High School League has canceled the spring athletics and fine arts season.

h2.a: What is happening with second trimester report cards?

div.p: Second trimester report cards that are now available online in Campus Parent Portal. For many families, this is a new way to access report cards. Watch a video tutorial on how to access your student’s report card.

h2.a: Is the school year being extended?

div.p: No. The state is not requiring the school year be extended.

h2.a: What if I still have things at school that I need?

div.p: If you have things you absolutely need that have been left at school, please leave a message with your school's front office.

h2.a: How will you communicate any changes to how schools are operating?

div.p: We are communicating with staff and families as we do with weather-related alerts – email, text, phone message, and website. The website – springlakeparkschools.org/coronavirus is the hub for the latest information and resources as we move forward.
If you are not receiving communication as you prefer, please see instructions under Notification System for updating your information.

Click on the links below to view information about each key topic.

div.h3: Monitor the status of Schoology and Seesaw

div.p:
The SLP Tech Department is here to support students and families during extended flexible learning.
If you need technology support, email techsupport@district16.org. Make sure to include your name, contact information and a brief description of your request. If you are unable to email, call 763-600-5555 and leave a message.

ul.li: Minnesota Department of Health – Information about COVID-19 and specific impacts to Minnesota.
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention – General information
Information for Travel that may be especially relevant for families returning from spring break trips.
Call the MDH COVID-19 Hotline at 651-201-3920, Monday - Friday from 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.

li.a: How to talk with children about Coronavirus

a.title: Powered by Finalsite opens in a new window

article.h2: Important Message: School year to conclude through extended flexible learning; Buildings remain closed

div.p: Governor Walz has ordered K-12 schools in Minnesota to remain closed through the end of the 2019-2020 school year. In addition, the Minnesota State High School League has canceled the spring athletic and fine arts season.
The school year will be completed through extended flexible learning.

There will be no student instruction May 1 and May 4 as teachers plan for the rest of the year. The governor had previously closed schools through April 30 with planning days on May 1 and May 4 in anticipation of schools reopening on May 5. We will use these planning days to prepare for the last six weeks of the year.
Meal services for children in our community and childcare for health care workers and first responders continues.
While this is not how we wanted to end the school year, we remained focused on making the best of this situation and thankful for the support and partnership of our learning community.
Find a full update at SpringLakeParkSchools.org/Coronavirus
